has a geometrical origin related to the Mo and S sublattices,

exhibits an anisotropy arising from the triangular geometry of the atomic arrangement. Particularly, the gradient

imparts such an unidirectional force on
) are absent due to the odd parity of
. It prohibits the excitation of the interlayer shear
directions. Although the y-polarized light pulse lowers the energy barrier along the
directions, it cannot induce the ferroelectric switching along these directions. Therefore, the most effective way to
realize the ferroelectric switching is to use the x-polarized light pulse which induces both the interlayer shear
motion and energy barrier lowering along the
direction for the ferroelectric switching to occur.
Next, we analyze the dynamics of ferroelectric switching based on the
pulse. First, we considered a case neglecting the damping of normal modes to simply show the essential conse-
modes at 0 K and 300 K, respectively, without damping under the x-polarized pulse with
100 fs. The initial vibration amplitudes were set as the mean-square-displacement
according to the Bose-Einstein distribution at each temperature. The initial vibration of
aligned to the y-axis by setting the initial coordinate as
. This results in the initial amplitudes of
modes oscillate with the harmonic frequencies before the arrival of the pulse at
0 ps. The initial kinetic energy of
late with larger amplitude with respect to the shifted minimum at
shift in the effective potential minimum). The pumping does not affect the motion of
) as there are no forcing terms on it. The kinetic energy of
increased to 1.6 meV by the anharmonic energy flow from the pumped
mode. It is noted that the pulse and
should be in-phase because the anharmonic force is unidirectional. The vibration of
small region because the kinetic energy is still smaller than the effective barrier of
. In contrast, the oscillatory curve of

is yet below the static energy barrier
17.3 meV, but higher than the effective barrier
mode jumped over the barrier and oscillated with colossal ampli-
. The vibration corresponds to the repetitive interconversion between
AB and AC stackings, due to the absence of damping.
Secondly, a more realistic model that includes the damping of the normal modes was considered. The damping
were taken as 2% of the harmonic frequencies, which are similar to the experimental
modes initially oscillate with small amplitudes at 0 K until the arrival of the
first pulse at 0 ps (damping is turned on at 0 ps). The eight sequencial pulses are applied to substantially amplify
mode from the zero-point vibration at 0 K. The time interval between the subsequent pulses is gradually
~ 1.6 ps for the phase matching between the pulse and
the increase in the period of
mode due to anharmonicity. Upon each cycle of pulse irradiation, the
is coherently amplified by gaining kinetic energy. After the eight pulses are irradiated, the
kinetic energy and jump over the effective barrier which is reduced by the
mode. Once the initial AB stacking
sequence changes to the AC stacking, it maintains the AC stacking due to the dissipation of the kinetic energies
of the vibrations. This corresponds to the AB
AC ferroelectric switching. The opposite switching operation,
AB, can be performed by the same optical input as illustrated in Fig.
